ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about German culture and language through this course! I also picked up on some important study habits for quiz-taking.

I learned a lot of German, both vocabulary and sentence structure. By the time I finished this class I was able to communicate in simple terms about many activities related to daily life. I reached the B1 (intermediate) fluency level of the CEFR and am planning to study abroad in Badem-Wurttemberg this summer  I think I'll be able to get by.
German reading, writing, listening, and speaking at an A2 level.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I enjoyed the structure of each class under Professor Sippel. It was nice to have each lesson parallel with what our course book was teaching. I dont think there was any weaknesses.

The class is extremely well-structured for learning  each day is well-planned with different activities (small group and whole class discussion, vocabulary review, free-writing, watching and responding to German-language videos, etc.). We studied new vocabulary on Quizlet every week and had pen pals at a gymnasium in Nuremberg. "Asynchronous" Wednesday classes consisted of watching and summarizing episodes of a language-learning TV show, reading and responding to articles on Canvas, and sometimes other activities (we read a short story by Kafka and poetry by Theodor Storm). I didn't mind this structure or the work, but I found the independent work in the textbook (a new one was used I think starting this year) to be unsatisfying. The Ubungen assignments felt like busywork. We had to fill them out on paper (I think a digital interface would have helped a lot) and then grade ourselves, which was dull and time-consuming.

The Ubungen feel very much like busy-work that doesn't provide an equal payout in terms of knowledge growth for the amount of time it takes to do them. I would feel much more productive and capable in my German if I had redirected my Ubungen time to just repeating the Quizlets.

Also, GMAN 110 had a better email exchange format than GMAN 120. New topics every week meant that we were never replying to questions asked in the response emails of the previous week....i.e. no longitudinal conversations.

Strengths:
- The course is very thoroughly planned. All assignments and class content for each day are clearly laid out on the syllabus.
- The instructor was engaging, caring, and adjusted to students' individual levels.
- The seminar style format of the class facilitated interaction between students, who were all very friendly and interested in the class content.

Weaknesses:
- The workload can at times be overwhelming. For instance, there are days when more than one assignment is due. It is not easy to stay on top of deadlines.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, absolutely. It was the perfect amount of workload to effectively learn German and each class was interesting and fun.
Yes, it's a very thoughtful and well-structured continuing introduction to German language and culture.
Yes. This is a great opportunity to significantly improve one's German skills in a relatively short span of time.
